Fischer-Tropsch synthesis is an important reaction route to produce liquid fuels from syngas. Based on the chemical reaction engineering perspective, Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) kinetics plays an important role in the reactor development and process scale-up. A Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Waston (LHHW) type model of CO consumption kinetics is built from the carbide mechanism. Firstly, the functional equation of the ratio of the consumption rate of H2, H2O, and CO is obtained based on the regression of the experimental data as fH 2 and fH 2 O, and then the model kinetic parameters were regressed by the least squares method. The accuracy of the model was verified by the F-test. Meanwhile, the operating conditions of the FTS reaction were optimized to determine the maximum CO conversion. To improve the catalytic efficiency, Radial Basis Function Neural Networks (RBFNN) was used to realize the prediction of CO conversion at the exit of FTS reaction. Based on the two-layer stochastic optimization algorithm, the parameters of neural network and the operating conditions were adjusted and optimized. This paper compares the differences and connections between the two approaches, the mechanism model and the neural network model mentioned above, for the prediction of FTS reaction simulation. Introduction Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) is a complex reaction system that generates hydrocarbon-based products from syngas (H2 and CO) under the action of a catalyst, which is a key step in the indirect liquefaction process of coal to produce clean, non-polluting, and environmentally friendly liquid fuels [1–5]. Typically, FTS catalysts include mainly iron-based and cobalt-based catalysts. Iron-based catalysts have wide operating temperatures, low methane selectivity, and high flexibility, and there were suitable for FTS processes with low ratio of hydrogen to carbon [6,7]. Cobalt-based catalysts were generally used in low-temperature FTS to produce long chains hydrocarbons [8,9]. Due to the complexity of the FTS pathway and the numerous radical reactions involved, a unified reaction mechanism is currently lacking. To optimize the operating conditions of the FTS reaction and improve the CO conversion, this paper builds a FTS reactor model based on LHHW-type reaction kinetics and RBF neural network from the perspectives of mechanism modeling and neural network modeling. The model parameters were determined by regression analysis of experimental data obtained from the slurry bed stirred kettle reactor [10,11]. Comparing the two modeling methods, the mechanism modeling usually adopts the assumptions such as aggregate classification of reaction components and introduction of constant volumetric flow rate of feedstock, which reduces the reliability of the model. The artificial neural network has a powerful nonlinear function fitting ability, which can extract the functional coupling relationship between the reaction operating conditions and the reaction exit variables [12,13]. However, the reaction mechanism is not clear from the characteristic analysis of the modeling problem. The results show that both the black-box model constructed with neural network and the simplified mechanism model have good prediction effect on the conversion rate of Fischer-Tropsch synthesized CO. Experimental Catalyst preparation The Fe-based catalysts used in this study were prepared by a combination of precipitation and spray drying. In brief, the appropriate amount of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and NH4OH were dissolved in deionized water and the pH was adjusted to about 9.0. The temperature was maintained at 60 °C during the precipitation process. At the end of the precipitation, the obtained precipitate was filtered and washed to neutrality and then spray dried. The obtained samples were sieved into 80–100 mesh particles and impregnated with KHCO3 solution to obtain the desired potassium content. Finally, the samples were dried at 120 °C for 24 h, and then calcined at 450 °C for 6 h. Catalytic evaluation Catalyst performance tests were performed in a 1-litre continuously stirred tank reactor loaded with 10.0 g of the catalyst and 600 g of liquid paraffin. Prior to entering the reactor, H2 and CO were passed through a series of purge traps to remove trace of oxygen, sulfur, carbonyls, and water, respectively. The flow rates of H2 and CO were controlled by two mass flow meters. The reactor outlet was connected to a hot trap (393 K) and a cold trap (273 K) at the system pressure. A wet gas flow meter was used to monitor the flow rate of the tail gas. Catalyst activation was carried out in situ using different reducing agents (H2, CO, H2/CO = 2.58) for 24 h at 538 K, 2000 h − 1 and 2.70 MPa. After activation, FTS performance was tested at 523 ‒ 553 K, 1.0 ‒ 3.0 MPa, and H2/CO = 2.0 ‒ 5.0, respectively. The tail gas was analyzed on-line using a gas chromatography (GC) (models 6890 N, Agilent) equipped with a 16-port sampling valve. The hydrocarbons were analyzed with an Al2O3 capillary column (HP-PLOT, 30 m × 0.53 mm × 0.25 μm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). H2, N2, CO, CO2, and CH4 were analyzed with a Porapak Q column (2 m × 3 mm) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The products in oil phase were analyzed off-line by GC (model 6890 N, Agilent) with a quartz capillary column (DB-1, 60 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) and an FID. Oxygenates in water were analyzed off-line using GC (model 6890 N; Agilent) with a quartz capillary column (DB-WAX, 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm) and an FID. For the Fe FTS, we mainly focus on the CO conversion. The corresponding calculation formulas were listed in the following: X co ( % ) = F CO in − F CO out F CO in × 100 % Where XCO can be calculated with the CO mole flow rate in the feed and product flow. Prior to the intrinsic kinetic studies, the effect of internal mass transfer of catalyst has been eliminated via investigating the effect of catalyst particle size on reaction rate and product distribution. The results showed that the effect of internal mass transfer could be excluded for catalyst particle sizes of 80–100 mesh (0.15–0.18 mm). Mechanistic modeling FTS is a complex catalytic reaction process with a wide distribution of products, and detailed derivation of its kinetics is complex and difficult to calculate. In this paper, based on the relevant radical reaction of carbide mechanism, the kinetic expression of CO consumption of LHHW type was derived by taking the hypomethyl-generating radical reaction as the rate-determining step [14–16]. The constructing the set-total kinetic model and considering the effects of H2 and H2O partial pressure on the reaction process to realize the accurate prediction of CO consumption. The reaction system of FTS over iron-based catalyst includes the following reactions to generate straight-chain alkanes, α-olefins, H2O and CO2: (1) n CO + 2 n H 2 = C n H 2 n + n H 2 O (2) n CO + ( 2 n + 1 ) H 2 = C n H 2 n + 2 + n H 2 O (3) CO + H 2 O = C O 2 + H 2 Based on the idea of set totalization, the total reaction equation of FTS can be obtained as: (4) CO + f H 2 H 2 → f n C n H 2 n + f n ′ C n H 2 n + 2 + f H 2 O H 2 O + f C O 2 C O 2 where f H2, fn and f'n are the stoichiometric coefficients for hydrogen and hydrocarbons, respectively. f H2O and f CO2 are the stoichiometric coefficients for water and carbon dioxide, respectively. Yates et al. [17] investigated the effect of CO2 partial pressure on the rate of FTS reaction over iron-based catalysts in a slurry bed reactor and concluded that the effect due to CO2 is negligible. Results and discussion Experimental flow The macroscopic kinetic experiments of industrial iron-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis were carried out in a high-pressure slurry bed reactor (H/D = 2.5) with an effective volume of 1.0 L. The experimental setup is shown in Fig. 1 . The reactor is equipped with an electric heating furnace for heating and temperature control, and an annular gas distributor and a double-layer propeller stirrer to ensure that the catalyst is uniformly distributed and fully reacted with the syngas in the reactor. Under a certain operating temperature and pressure of the reactor, H2 and CO cylinders are continuously and quantitatively fed with syngas components to the reactor to fully contact and react with the catalyst. The gas-phase products of the reaction and the unreacted syngas are discharged from the exhaust pipe equipped with a filter and enter a heat trap (120 °C) to obtain the condensed wax phase. The non-condensable gas passes through a back-pressure valve and enters a jacket cooler for cooling to obtain the oil-water mixture, which is further separated to obtain the oil and water phases. The exhaust gas from the jacket cooler is divided into two parts, one is measured by a wet flow meter and then analyzed by chromatography, and the other part of the remaining gas is measured and then exhausted as exhaust gas. In the macroscopic kinetic modeling study and design of the experiments, the effects of four factors, namely, reaction temperature (T), reaction pressure (P), airspeed (GHSV), and feed gas hydrogen-carbon ratio (RH2/CO), on the reaction process were investigated. Orthogonal design was used to test the operating points and the reaction was carried out for more than 24 h after each change of operating conditions to ensure that the reaction reached a steady state. The average relative error of the model prediction of CO conversion rate is 8.20%. Meanwhile, we collected a large amount of industrial FTS data for Fe-based catalysts for model validation, and the data error was less than 12%. It is generally accepted that an error of less than 15% in model validation can satisfy the requirements of industrial design. Optimization of operating conditions In the process flow of industrial FTS, unreacted syngas will be captured and pooled before being distributed and circulated to different FTS reactors, and CO conversion is one of the main factors affecting the size of the circulating gas flow [19–21]. Industrial iron-based FTS refers to kinetic modeling studies of catalysts used for actual industrial production, which were used to further speculate on optimal industrial production conditions. Therefore, design optimization of the process operating conditions is needed to improve the reaction efficiency and reduce the recycling cost [22–26]. Neglecting the catalyst deactivation process and assuming that the CO reaction rate is only a function of the reaction temperature, reaction pressure, feed hydrogen-carbon ratio and air velocity, an optimization model was developed. The sensitivity analysis was performed for each operating condition on the CO conversion, and then the gradient descent method was used to simultaneously optimize the above four operating conditions, which resulted in the maximum CO conversion for FTS in a high-pressure slurry bed with an effective volume of 1 L. The optimization model was developed for the FTS reactor and the optimization model was developed for the FTS reactor and the optimization model was developed for the FTS reactor. The proposed kinetic model of the FTS is expected to be used to speculate individual key parameters in industrial FTS to guide practical production. Model I : OBJ = max { XCO ( T , P , GHSV , R H 2 / CO ) } Combining Eqs. (5), (6), (7), (8), and (11), the reaction was carried out at T [240 °C, 280 °C]; P [2.0 MPa,4.0 MPa]; RH2/CO [2.0,5.0]; GHSV [220 mL-(g-min)−1300 mL ( g · min ) − 1 ]; the base conditions of the reaction were T = 240 °C, P = 2.5 MPa, RH2/CO=2.0 and GHSV=260 mL ( g · min ) − 1 , and three of the operating conditions were kept unchanged, and the sensitivity analyses were performed separately for the remaining operating conditions, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . Since the CO conversion has the highest sensitivity to temperature, XCO will increase from 42% to 67% when the reaction temperature is increased from 240 to 280 °C, and XCO varies in the range of 38% to 48% for the remaining three operating conditions. Among them, XCO increases and then decreases with the increase of reaction pressure, and the curve is quadratically convex, with the peak value of XCO appearing near P = 2.9 MPa; the airspeed magnitude is linearly and negatively correlated with XCO, i.e., with the increase of airspeed, the XCO decreases linearly; XCO decreases and then increases with the increase of the hydrogen-carbon ratio, and the curve is quadratically concave, with the valley value of XCO appearing near RH2/CO=2.75. Therefore, to obtain a higher CO conversion, under the premise of ensuring the catalyst activity and capacity requirements, the reaction temperature can be increased and the operating airspeed can be reduced, while keeping the reaction pressure near 2.9 MPa and the feed hydrogen-carbon ratio higher or lower than 2.75. Simultaneous optimization of the above four operating conditions was carried out, and the solver conopt4 was used to solve the model I. The operating conditions for a maximum 71.3 % CO conversion were obtained. The operating conditions of T = 280 °C, P = 3.016 MPa, RH2/CO=2.0 and GHSV=220 mL·(g·min)−1 were obtained, which were consistent with the results obtained from the sensitivity analysis. Five surface steps are assumed in the derivation of the kinetic model: (1) adsorption of reactants (CO and H2), (2) chain initiation, (3) chain growth, (4) chain termination and desorption of products, and (5) re-adsorption of olefins and secondary reactions. The dissociative adsorption of hydrogen is considered to occur in both the molecular and dissociative states. The model was well fitted to experimental data under industrially relevant conditions. The kinetic model was of the power-law type, where the reaction rate was a function of the partial pressure of reactants and products. The kinetics is not strictly based on the real reaction mechanisms, which also takes into account the formation of hydrocarbon chain growth initiating block, re-adsorption of olefins, methane generation, suppression of CO2 production, etc. Therefore, the model is limited to exploring operational conditions of industrial significance. Radial basis neural network Due to the wide distribution of products generated by the FTS reaction and the complexity of the mechanism, it is necessary to appropriately simplify the assumptions during the modeling of the above mechanism and to use the step-by-step method to estimate the stoichiometric coefficients of hydrogen and water first before completing the construction of the kinetic model [27–29]. RBF neural networks, which are three-layer feed-forward networks with a single implicit layer, have been shown to be more effective in terms of approximation capability, classification capability, and training speed direction [30,31]. The topology of the network is shown in Fig. 5 , where n denotes the dimension of the input variables of the neural network and m denotes the dimension of the output variables of the neural network. The input layer linearly processes and weights the input variables and outputs the results to the hidden layer with Z nodes; the neurons in the hidden layer respond to the input signals by using the radial basis function as the activation function, and nonlinearly transform them, and then output the obtained results after weighting and calculating the upper bias; the output layer receives the outputs from the hidden layer and outputs them as the final results of the whole neural network after linear processing output. The RBF neural network is used to construct the kinetic model of FTS reaction, which can be directly trained to obtain the mapping function relationship between the input variables and the output results under the condition that the input variables and the output results are known and can be used for the production prediction. Particle swarm algorithm to optimize network parameters The RBF neural network is continuously adjusted by the center and width of the radial basis function and the size of the weights between the hidden layer and the input-output layer in order to obtain a network model with better prediction results [32–35]. The data for the RBF neural network model was derived from catalyst activity data obtained in a slurry bed FTS reactor. The mean square error threshold (MSE), the learning speed (Spread), the maximum number of neurons in the hidden layer (MN) and the neuron incremental tolerance (DF) are the main network parameters affecting the training effect of RBF neural networks. Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) is used to optimize the above four network parameters in outer loop iterations, so that the RBF neural network trained based on the training set has the smallest Average Relative Error of Prediction (AREVal) for the validation set, and the prediction effect is tested by the test set, the basic parameters of the neural network and the PSO algorithm are shown in Table 4 . The basic parameters of the neural network and particle swarm algorithm are set as shown in Table 4. The RBF neural network model was constructed using a total of 298 sets of FTS experimental data with the following range of operating conditions: operating conditions range: T∈[230 °C,280 °C]; P∈[1.0 MPa,4.0 MPa]; RH2/CO∈[1.0,5.0]; GHSV∈[100 mL·(g·min)−1, 240 mL·(g·min)−1]. The 298 sets of experimental data were divided into training set, validation set and test set according to 7:2:1, and after optimization and adjustment of the basic parameters of the RBF neural network using the PSO algorithm, the magnitude of the error between the predicted value and the actual value of each dataset was obtained as shown in Fig. 6 . Among them, the average relative errors of the training set, validation set and test set are obtained to be 10.0%, 7.93% and 8.65%, respectively, which basically meet the design requirements of the industrial operating conditions. Genetic algorithm to optimize F-T operating conditions GeneticAlgorithm (GA) is a stochastic algorithm that searches for an optimal solution by simulating a natural evolutionary process. After the construction of the RBF neural network is completed, the GA can be continuously updated to evolve the population individuals containing the four operating conditions (temperature, pressure, airspeed, and hydrogen-carbon ratio), and the population with the optimal fitness (CO conversion rate) is obtained after M generations of evolution [36,37]. The flowchart of the algorithm is shown in Fig. 7 , where Pc is the probability of cross-evolution occurring between population individuals, and Pm is the probability of natural mutation occurring in an individual within the population [38–43]. When the maximum number of evolutionary generations M = 50 and each generation of the population contains 10 individuals, the optimal fitness of the population obtained is 78.9%, and the optimal individuals are T = 253 °C, P = 3.94 MPa, RH2/CO= 2.29 and GHSV= 190 mL·(g·min)−1. Since the neural network neglects the relationship between the input variable (operating conditions) and the output variable (CO conversion rate) mechanism level function, it only estimates the CO conversion rate by performing a special weighted summation of the operating conditions, and the genetic algorithm optimization is inherently stochastic in nature [43–48]. Therefore, the optimization results are somewhat different from the sensitivity analysis. The model optimization conditions were not significantly different from the industrial operating conditions. The model optimization conditions: T = 553 K, P = 3.016 MPa, RH2/CO = 2.0, GHSV = 220 mL·g − 1·min−1. However, more consideration will be given to the plant economics in the actual industrial operation. Industrial operating conditions: T = 548 K, P = 2.80 MPa, RH2/CO = 3.5 ‒ 3.8, and GHSV=0.96 Nm3·g − 1·min−1. The model optimization conditions provide a theoretical basis for the operating conditions of industrial operations. Conclusion Based on the kinetic expression of CO consumption rate of LHHW type, a stepwise method was used to construct a set kinetic model of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis reaction, which considered the stoichiometric coefficients of hydrogen and water changing with the change of operating conditions, and the accurate prediction of CO conversion could be realized, and the average relative error of prediction on 20 sets of experimental data was 8.20%. Simultaneous optimization of reaction temperature, pressure, air velocity and hydrogen-carbon ratio using the gradient descent method resulted in a CO conversion of up to 71.3%. To simplify the model building process, an RBF neural network was used to directly construct the function mapping of operating conditions and CO conversion rate, and a two-layer stochastic optimization algorithm (PSO and GA) was used to optimize the basic parameters of the neural network and the operating conditions, respectively. The average relative error of the RBF neural network obtained from the training based on 208 sets of experimental data was 8.65 % for the prediction of 31 sets of experimental data, and the highest CO conversion rate of up to 78.9% could be achieved by using genetic algorithms to optimize the operating conditions. The RBF neural network model is simple compared to the mechanistic modeling process of LHHW, and a high prediction accuracy can be ensured without many simplifying assumptions, but the prediction accuracy of the network is strongly dependent on the dimensional range of the training data, and it cannot predict the results of the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis reaction outside the range of the operating conditions of the training data very well. The mechanism model, on the other hand, overcomes the limitations of the neural network and is suitable for the prediction of unknown operating conditions and the optimization of operating conditions. coredata.dc:description: Fischer-Tropsch synthesis is an important reaction route to produce liquid fuels from syngas. Based on the chemical reaction engineering perspective, Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) kinetics plays an important role in the reactor development and process scale-up. A Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Waston (LHHW) type model of CO consumption kinetics is built from the carbide mechanism. Firstly, the functional equation of the ratio of the consumption rate of H2, H2O, and CO is obtained based on the regression of the experimental data as fH 2 and fH 2 O, and then the model kinetic parameters were regressed by the least squares method. The accuracy of the model was verified by the F-test. Meanwhile, the operating conditions of the FTS reaction were optimized to determine the maximum CO conversion. To improve the catalytic efficiency, Radial Basis Function Neural Networks (RBFNN) was used to realize the prediction of CO conversion at the exit of FTS reaction. Based on the two-layer stochastic optimization algorithm, the parameters of neural network and the operating conditions were adjusted and optimized. This paper compares the differences and connections between the two approaches, the mechanism model and the neural network model mentioned above, for the prediction of FTS reaction simulation.
coredata.dc:title: Kinetics modeling and operating conditions optimization of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis over Fe-based catalysts
